docs.abstract: The third year of medical school has long been a pivotal point in training, but recently, the tradition of monthlong "rotations," a speed-dating introduction to the major disciplines of medicine and the issues patients face, has come under fire.
docs.snippet: The third year of medical school has long been a pivotal point in training, but recently, the tradition of monthlong "rotations," a speed-dating introduction to the major disciplines of medicine and the issues patients face, has come under fire.

headline.main: Life, Interrupted: A Young Cancer Patient Faces Infertility
headline.print_headline: A Patient for Now, but Maybe a Mother Someday

docs.abstract: Last spring, I found out I had leukemia. Before the horror of the news even had time to sink in, I had to absorb a second shock: The chemotherapy treatments that could save my life would also make me infertile, writes Suleika Jaouad.
docs.snippet: Last spring, I found out I had leukemia. Before the horror of the news even had time to sink in, I had to absorb a second shock: The chemotherapy treatments that could save my life would also make me infertile, writes Suleika Jaouad.

docs.lead_paragraph: A decline in the rate of teenage pregnancy is largely the result of an increase in birth control use. Yet Mitt Romney wants to dismantle reproductive health programs.
docs.abstract: Editorial cites Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report finding steep decline in the rate of teen pregnancy; contends shift is clearly attributable to the increased use of contraception; chastises Republicans who support repealing the Affordable Care Act, which contains a provision that will help prevent many more teenage pregnancies.
docs.snippet: A decline in the rate of teenage pregnancy is largely the result of an increase in birth control use. Yet Mitt Romney wants to dismantle reproductive health programs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislation would carry out a 1992 court ruling that called for an exception to a constitutional ban if pregnancy threatened a woman’s life.

headline.seo: Ireland Takes Up Bill on Abortion Access
headline.main: Ireland Takes Up Bill on Abortion Access
headline.print_headline: Irish Parliament Takes Up Bill on Abortion Access 20 Years After Court Cleared Way

docs.abstract: Irish Parliament begins debate on a bill that would provide for limited access to abortion if there is a risk to the life of the mother; in this conservative and Catholic nation, however, sentiment against abortion runs strong, and over the past few months anti-abortion groups have been pressuring politicians to oppose the bill, and are confident it will be defeated.
docs.snippet: Legislation would carry out a 1992 court ruling that called for an exception to a constitutional ban if pregnancy threatened a woman’s life.

docs.lead_paragraph: An abortion provider questions the existence of “abortion survivors.”
docs.snippet: An abortion provider questions the existence of “abortion survivors.”

docs.abstract: For the first time since three female Supreme Court justices have been sitting together, the court considered a sex discrimination claim. They ended up on the losing side.
docs.snippet: For the first time since three female Supreme Court justices have been sitting together, the court considered a sex discrimination claim. They ended up on the losing side.

docs.abstract: Maybe some of us simply weren't built to be vegans. Is the diet good for everyone?
docs.snippet: Maybe some of us simply weren't built to be vegans. Is the diet good for everyone?

docs.lead_paragraph: The individual contributions of hypertension, diabetes and obesity in mothers are not clear, but the increased risks to their children are more than double for developmental delays and more than 50 percent for autism, a study suggests.

headline.seo: Diabetes or Obesity in Pregnancy Tied to Developmental Delays
headline.main: Hazards: Poor Health in Pregnancy Linked to Delays
headline.print_headline: Hazards: Poor Health in Pregnancy Linked to Delays

docs.abstract: Dr Irva Hertz-Picciotto study in journal Pediatrics finds that a mother’s diabetes, hypertension or obesity during pregnancy may increase her child’s risk of autism and developmental problems.
docs.snippet: The individual contributions of hypertension, diabetes and obesity in mothers are not clear, but the increased risks to their children are more than double for developmental delays and more than 50 percent for autism, a study suggests.

docs.lead_paragraph: According to a report from the National Center for Health Statistics, birth rates among young women ages 15 to 19 fell in all but three states and in all racial, ethnic and age groups. From 2009 to 2010, the rate of teenage births fell by 9 percent, to 34.9 per thousand, the lowest rate ever reported in the 65 years for which data is available. ''I think the current generation of youth are perhaps more conscientious and cautious,'' said Dr. John Santelli, a professor of clinical population and family health at Columbia University who was not involved in writing the report.

headline.main: Teenage Birth Rate Is Lowest Since 1946

docs.abstract: Report by the National Center for Health Statistics finds that birth rates among teenagers fell 9 percent from 2009 to 2010, to 34.9 per thousand, the lowest rate since 1946. (M)
